description: From Middle English greven, from Old French grever (“to burden”), from Latin gravō, gravāre, from adjective gravis (“grave”).

verbs.description: grieve (third-person singular simple present grieves, present participle grieving, simple past and past participle grieved)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause sorrow or distress to.
examples: Thy maidens griev'd themselves at my concern.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To feel very sad about; to mourn; to sorrow for.
(transitive) To submit or file a grievance (about).
examples: Even if the executive director rules against the employee on appeal, the employee can still grieve the termination to the superintendent followed by an appeal to the [...] Board of Trustees.

description:
From Middle English greve, greyve, grave, grafe, from Old Norse greifi, from Middle Low German grēve, grâve,
related to Old English grœfa, groefa, variants of Old English ġerēfa (“steward, reeve”). More at reeve.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A governor of a town or province.
(chiefly Scotland) A manager or steward, e.g. of a farm.
